title: Common Data Problems Solved with Graphs Using Azure Cosmos DB Gremlin API
abstract: In this presentation, you will get a better understanding of what graph databases are, how to use the Gremlin API within Azure Cosmos DB to traverse such data structures, and see practical examples to common data problems.
description:
Data as it appears in the real world is naturally connected, but traditional data modeling focuses on entities which can cause for complicated joins of these naturally connected data.  That is where graph databases come in as they store data more like what happens naturally in the real world.  Sure, there a lot of talk about using graph databases for social networks, recommendation engines, and Internet of Things; but using graph databases can also make a lot of sense when working with common business data problems.

In this presentation, you will get a better understanding of what graph databases are, how to use the Gremlin API within Azure Cosmos DB to traverse such data structures, and see practical examples to common data problems.

name: Bill Dinger
bio:
Bill is a Solutions Architect with VML working on delivering digital solutions to our clients. Over the last 15 years Bill has worked in enterprise IT starting in the trenches on the help desk. After that, Bill spent almost a decade working in infrastructure support focusing in the Microsoft stack. Over the last 5 years Bill has been developing, architecting and leading teams of software developers with VML. During that time Bill has done everything from troubleshoot dial up connections in rural Nebraska to building the digital experiences for some of America's most well known brands.

When not working, Bill will probably be found on his bike exploring gravel roads in his hometown of Lincoln, Nebraska.
title: Continuous Everything: Deliver on the promise of DevOps
abstract: The promise of DevOps is about bringing quality & speed of delivery to technology organizations. In this talk we'll go over real world experiences of how to build continuous integration, delivery, security, quality and everything in between into your projects using mostly free & open source tools.
description:
We'll go over the full CI/CD cycle: builds, commit hooks, static code analysis, pull request review tools, automated linting, continuous QA/Security/Release automation and everything in between. Gained from years of practical experience Iâ€™ll share what has worked best on projects cross industry and from teams ranging for 2 to 140.

Additionally, where applicable docker containers, source code, and reference materials will of course be freely available to all attendees. By attending this course you will learn how you can improve speed, improve quality, improve security, improve performance and reduce headaches by embracing everything about the modern DevOps cycle.
notes: This talk will be focused on a couple common technologies - Jenkins, Webpage test private instances, Docker, OWASP ZAP, Git, Node, Selenium, Sonarqube, etc. My company works for Fortune 500 companies all across the United States and the world. As part of that work we usually have found it necessary to stand up our own stack of CI/CD tooling as the companies typically have a fragmented ecosystem that they aren't particularly keen to share. My real world experience is based on leading the teams behind various projects including the DevOps tooling behind Sprint.com, Ford.com, US Soccer, and Bridgestone.

name: Bill Dinger
bio:
Bill is a Solutions Architect with VML working on delivering digital solutions to our clients. Over the last 15 years Bill has worked in enterprise IT starting in the trenches on the help desk. After that, Bill spent almost a decade working in infrastructure support focusing in the Microsoft stack. Over the last 5 years Bill has been developing, architecting and leading teams of software developers with VML. During that time Bill has done everything from troubleshoot dial up connections in rural Nebraska to building the digital experiences for some of America's most well known brands.

When not working, Bill will probably be found on his bike exploring gravel roads in his hometown of Lincoln, Nebraska.
title: Continuous Security: Integrate OWASP tools into your DevOps Pipeline
abstract: OWASP provides a number of free and open source tools designed by security experts to help your secure your applications. Learn how to integrate these tools - from active penetration tests to project dependency checkers - into your DevOps pipeline and deliver on the promise of continuous security.
description: OWASP has a number of flagship projects designed to help us deliver secure applications. The [OWASP Depedency Check](https://www.owasp.org/index.php/OWASP_Dependency_Check) works with Java, .NET, and Javascript dependencies to check for known security vulnerabilities. The [OWASP ZAP](https://www.owasp.org/index.php/OWASP_Zed_Attack_Proxy_Project) is a attack proxy to actively probe your application and the [OWTF (offensive web testing framework)](https://www.owasp.org/index.php/OWASP_OWTF). Finally, we'll go over the [Application Security Verification Series (ASVS)](https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Category:OWASP_Application_Security_Verification_Standard_Project) as it applies to your DevOps toolchain itself to make sure you know and are securing your pipeline itself.
notes: I'm passionate about building all the necessary tooling for developers to deliver quality, secure applications. I'm equally passionate about using great free & open source tooling to do so from the fine folks at OWASP.  My company works for Fortune 500 companies all across the United States and the world. As part of that work we usually have found it necessary to stand up our own stack of CI/CD tooling as the companies typically have a fragmented ecosystem that they arenâ€™t particularly keen to share, and aren't very interested in spending money on any of this. My real world experience is based on leading the teams behind various projects including the DevOps tooling behind Sprint.com, Ford.com, US Soccer, and Bridgestone. This talk has previously been given at Little Rock Tech Fest.

name: Ken Snyder
bio: I am a Software Craftsman passionate about JavaScript. I am the co-founder of UtahJS, an educational non-profit aimed at promoting JavaScript in Utah. I two Monthly JavaScript Meetups and the Annual UtahJS Conference.
title: Cross-Browser Extensions with the WebExtensions API
abstract: Writing browser extensions is no longer a secret and difficult art. With the new WebExtensions API standard, Web Developers of all levels can write valuable extensions that work on Chrome, Firefox and Edge.
description:
In years past, writing browser extensions has been a secret and difficult art:
- A Firefox add on was completely different than a Chrome extension
- Each browser release carried a significant risk of breaking your extension
- APIs were inconsistent, clunky and limited
- The extension runtime had different JavaScript language features

But we are in a new era. The WebExtensions API standard is accessible to all Web Developers:
- Identical extension code that works on Chrome, Firefox, and Edge
- APIs are stable across browser versions
- APIs are developed and standardized by committee
- First-class browser support for classes, async await, generators, destructuring, spreading and much more

In this presentation we'll make a cool browser extension that could compliment your company's web application.

name: Harold Schreckengost
bio: I work for CrossBrowserTesting doing DevOps and architecture, and live in Memphis, where I spend a lot of time working with the Memphis Technology Foundation community.
title: Cultural Agility
abstract: "We use SCRUM, we're agile now!" - we've all heard this, and seen the often lackluster results.  The problem isn't the tool, it's that we've been given chainsaws when we don't understand the tree.  This is a culture problem, and we can solve it with some work.
description: "We use SCRUM, we're agile now!" - we've all heard this, and seen the often lackluster results.  The problem isn't the tool, it's that we've been given chainsaws when we don't understand the tree.  This is a culture problem, and we can solve it with some work.  Come learn how to build a culture that supports the use of tools and frameworks like Jira, SCRUM, and Kanban, and how to get the most out of them, by getting the most out of yourself.

name: Justin James
bio: Justin is the founder of Let Your Nerd Be Heard, creator of the Ultimate Presentation Formula for Nerds, Award Winning Entrepreneur,  Amazon #1 Best Selling Author and a Microsoft MVP.  He is hired by techie nerds to get them confidently on stage speaking to more than 1s and 0s and seen as the go to expert.
title: Cypress: Where Automated Web UI Acceptance Testing Isnâ€™t Just for QA Anymore
abstract: Todayâ€™s fast-moving software delivery emphasizes pushing to production as quickly as possible with high quality.  This means we need to automated all of the testing including the UI.  With Cypress, we finally have a framework that allows every developer to create automated UI tests.
description:
Todayâ€™s fast-moving software delivery environment emphasizes pushing value to production as quickly as possible. â€œValue to productionâ€ implicitly requires high qualityâ€”low quality is of little value to anyone! â€”which means teams need to focus on being able to specify, build, test, and deploy software effectively and quickly. Acceptance testing historically been manually intensive efforts run by a dedicated QA department, resulting in a slower pace of production releases.

No longer do we have to make acceptance a manual effort that requires a dedicated QA department.   With the release of Cypress, we have a new standard in front-end testing that allows every developer to create acceptance tests.  Come learn how you can create fast, easy, and reliable test for anything that runs in a browser regardless of the front-end framework used.

You will walk away ready to end the era of â€œDevelopers donâ€™t write acceptance testsâ€ and start writing acceptance tests for all of your projects.

name: Patrick Wolff
bio: Patrick is passionate about collaboration, human computer interaction, graphic design and problem solving. His degree in Digital Imaging from the University of Nebraska at Omaha led him down a career path that includes television, advertising, Flash development for online learning, web development, enterprise application development, Geographic Information Systems, and leadership. Currently, Patrick serves as VP of Applications Development at Farm Credit Services of America.
title: Data Visualizations and Story Telling using Maps
abstract: Certain stories can only be told by visualizing your data points on a map. Geographic Information Systems (GIS) allow you to easily take your existing geographic based information, and present it in ways that can create aha moments for your organization. See how easily you can get started in GIS.
description:
Find out what Geographic Information Systems (GIS) are all about! 

GIS is a framework for gathering, managing, and analyzing data. Rooted in the science of geography, GIS integrates many types of data. It analyzes spatial location and organizes layers of information into visualizations using maps and 3D scenes. â€‹With this unique capability, GIS reveals deeper insights into data, such as patterns, relationships, and situationsâ€”helping users make smarter decisions. 


Learn what it takes to get started in GIS, and the sort of staff and budget you need. You may be surprised to find out that GIS has practical uses in a wide range of industries like Finance, Marketing, Retail, Government, etc. There are hundreds of configurable tools and services available to get started quickly and easily. 

We'll show you some examples of how to cross-reference some basic data sets to tell a story that will create a light bulb moment for business decision makers. 

Maps have never been so cool!
notes: Farme Credit Services of America started investing heavily into GIS two years ago. We've been able to build a small team filled with the top GIS talent in the region. Between three people, we have 60 years of experience in GIS.

name: John Le Drew
bio: John has spent most of the last 2 decades working in the software industry, with a focus on web technologies. After 10 years as a software engineer John moved into consultancy where he quickly learned the value of team dynamics and how most technical challenges are projecting underlying issues with collaboration. So his focus shifted, while still being very involved technically, his first focus is on facilitating a safe, creative, collaborative environment.
title: Diversity, chocolate and safe cracking.
abstract:
Diversity. It's the topic of the hour. 

But, do we want diverse teams because it's the "right thing to do"? Are we hiring minorities to keep up with quotas or our competition?

This talk will engage the audience in a frank discussion on what diversity is, why we need it and how we might achieve it.
description:
Diversity. It's the topic of the hour. Organisations are all putting 'diversity' and 'equal opportunities' on every job ad. But, for some organisations it still seems to be a struggle.

What's the goal? Do we want diverse teams because it's the "right thing to do" or is it "good for our teams and organisations"? Are we hiring minorities to keep up with quotas or our competition?

This talk will engage the audience in a frank discussion on what diversity is, why we need it and how we might achieve it. Guiding attendees through the latest research with practical exercises to demonstrate the issues and open discussion to find answers to the following questions:

* What does diversity mean? How does it relate to me? 
* Why does diversity matter in effective teams? 
* How can teams where everyone is different be effective? 
* How can we increase diversity in our organisations? 
* How can I employ a diverse group, when they are not applying?

Diversity is no longer just a moral imperative, it's critical to effective organisations.

## Learning Outcomes
* Understand how diversity relates to you.
* Understand what diversity is (and how it relates to inclusion and meritocracy).
* Understand why diversity is essential to effective teams.
* Understand the challenges diverse teams might face and how to overcome them.
* Understand how some organisations have incentivised greater number of applications from underrepresented groups.
* Understand how some organisations have created an inclusive environment.
notes:
This is a new session for me, but I'm an experienced speaker. Here is a rough breakdown of the session to give you an idea of the content.

## What diversity is. 
This is a presentation with a bit of discussion with the audience.

* Introduction, who I am and the background of the subject.
* Discussion on diversity, does it apply to you?
* The actual definitions of diversity, inclusion and meritocracy.

## Why diversity matters to effective teams. 
An introduction into current research on diversity and an exercise to explore why diversity leads to effective teams.

* Looking into the research, what does diversity have to do with anything?
* Safe cracking exercise to show why having a mixture of perspectives is important.
* How can we make a team work if everyone is different? What about conflict?

## How we can increase diversity in our teams.

* Discussion of how organisations have increased the diversity of their talent pipeline. 
* Discussion of how you create an inclusive environment.
* Closing

name: Kelly Andrews
bio:
Kelly J Andrews is a developer advocate and has been tinkering with computers for over 30 years, using BASIC for the first time at the age of 5.

 It wasn't until building his first webpage in 1997, and trying out JavaScript for the first time that he found a true calling. Kelly now fights for JavaScript, testable code, and fast delivery. 

In his free time you can find him singing karaoke, performing magic, or cheering for the Fighting Irish.
title: Docker: From Development to Production
abstract: In this talk, Kelly will walk through utilizing Docker through the entire development lifecycle, from development to production of a containerized application.
description:
Building applications across an organization can be a difficult process sometimes.  Developer machines can have variation that can end up causing confusion and difficulty at deployment time. This can not only be problematic for the developers, but also the DevOps team as well.

Moving application development to containers can reduce friction across all teams by simplifying the process in which new developers build and ship those applications.

In this talk, Kelly will walk through utilizing Docker through the entire development lifecycle, from development to production of a containerized application.  If you haven't started using containers, now is the time to learn how.
notes:
The technical requirements for this talk are very low, and should appeal to a broad group of developers and not any specific segment.  Most of the knowledge will be around understanding some Bash commands and creating a development environment. 

The container space has absolutely changed the way I write code. I have been evangelizing containers for about two years now.
additional_info: No travel assistance is required :)

name: Nathan Loding
bio:
Husband, father, developer, hacker ... nerd.

I'm a nerd, I've always been a geek, dork, or nerd, and probably will always be. I love solving problems and technology is the best way to do that. I work professionally as an Application Development Consultant for OST, in Grand Rapids, MI. I am the co-founder and lead developer on CareCircle, a new patient-centered healthcare product from OST. On the side I'm a husband, father, roboticist, and outdoorsman (hiking, camping, canoeing/kayaking). I enjoy woodworking and build my own canoes and kayaks. I hate chores and cleaning up after myself.
title: Empathy, chemotherapy, development: A journey
abstract: Chemotherapy, rare diseases, and hospitals stays may seem unrelated to development. Or are they? Follow me on my journey through selfishness and chemotherapy, to become a better developer. Learn to ask the right questions and deliver what is needed, not what is asked for.
description: My daughter was diagnosed with a rare disease in late 2015. She started chemotherapy in February of 2016 and we are still riding that train. It has been a whirlwind of emotions and support, or lack thereof. As we got further along in the treatments, the parallels between patient support and working with clients became clearer. The key takeaway - deliver what the client needs, not what they ask for. But how do you do that? And how does this relate to chemotherapy again? This is for more than just developers or consultants - everyone can walk away with something new.
notes: My daughter, now 5, has actually finished chemotherapy, but the rest of this is a true story. I did learn many lessons from support groups on how to better support my clients. These lessons can be transferred to projects whether or not the attendee is a developer or a consultant or devops, whether they work on client contracts or on a single product. Empathy is a hard topic to talk about, let alone grok and practice, but I hope I have a unique angle to illuminate the importance of empathy. I am a white male, not a person of color or a woman, so I can't speak much on diversity from that angle, other than to say we need to listen to what they have to say. I strongly suggest you pick a POC or woman over me for a diversity/empathy talk, but if you need a different perspective on it, I may be able to provide that.

name: David Mihal
bio: David is a freelance software engineer through Toptal who enjoys developing modern web-apps. He currently specializes in building Dapps on top of the Ethereum Blockchain. David lives a nomadic lifestyle and has worked from more than 40 countries in the last two years! In the past, David has worked on the Docs team at Google in NYC as well as HubSpot in Boston.
title: Ethereum is 1970s Technology
abstract: Blockchain technology has taken the world by storm! However, writing code for Ethereum, the self-proclaimed â€œworld computerâ€, presents a number of unique challenges. This talk will explain what Ethereum is and how developers need to learn from history to tackle some of these new challenges.
description:
Blockchain technology has taken the world by storm! Ethereum has become the most popular platform for developers to build exciting new blockchain applications. However, writing code for Ethereum, the self-proclaimed â€œworld computerâ€, presents a number of unique challenges. With expensive storage, limited RAM and â€œslowâ€ performance, writing code for Ethereum is almost like coding for a 1970s computer!

The talk will first outline what the Ethereum is, and how the Solidity programming language, Ethereum Virtual Machine and the Ethereum blockchain combine to act as a "world computer".

It will then outline some of the limitations of developing on Ethereum. While development in previous decades was limited by hardware, blockchain development is often limited by network constraints. Developers must be mindful of their code's execution time, storage and RAM usage, as these resources have monetary costs in the Ethereum ecosystem.

After outlining the constraints, various techniques of addressing these limitations will be presented.
additional_info: I may need assistance with travel expenses, but that can be discussed if my talk is accepted.

name: Billy Korando
bio: Billy is a developer advocate with IBM and has over a decade of experience. Billy is passionate about finding ways to reduce mental capacity waste from tedious work; such as project initation, deployment, testing and validation, and so on through automation and good management practices. Outside of work Billy enjoy traveling, playing kickball, and having his heartbroken by cheering on the Kansas City Chiefs.
title: Extending Spring Boot for Enterprise
abstract: Spring Boot has been an incredibly successful at reducing the time and complexity of spinning up new projects. However enterprise demands often cause Spring Boot projects to become bloated. In this presentation we will take Spring Boot's principle and learn how to apply them to the enterprise!
description:
Spring Boot has been an incredibly successful at reducing the time and complexity of spinning up new projects. However enterprise demands often cause Spring Boot projects to become bloated, out of date, and have inconsistent implementations, leading to them being difficult to maintain both for the teams responsible for a project and from an enterprise level of ensuring projects properly implement features like security, logging, database connectivity, and other common concerns.  

In this presentation we will look at some of the underlying philosophies of Spring Boot and see at how to apply them to the enterprise. Specific topics include creating customs starter libraries, BOMs, and easing project initialization steps all with the goal of reducing developer toil and frustration while ensuring consistent behavior across large enterprises but not blocking experimentation. If your organization has been struggling with bloated poms, projects full of dead code, and long pipelines from project conception to deployment to production this is a presentation you will definitely want to check out.
notes:
I have spoken extensively including at LavaOne, DevNexus, Spring I/O, and other user groups and conferences. I also have extensive experience with Spring having worked with it for over 8 years, and blogged and presented on it as well. Links to previous presentations and blog articles below:

Welcome to JUnit 5 @ LavaOne: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CC2ZdESKZNM   

What's New in Java 9 @ Spring Days Chicago: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EpORnEBsGoA&index=4&list=PLgGXSWYM2FpMWzCcNmCLOK2kpuquUbnKr

https://medium.com/@BillyKorando

https://keyholesoftware.com/category/series/automatedtestingseries/
additional_info: My company should be able to handle all travel expenses.

name: Chris DeMars
bio: Chris DeMars is a UI developer first, UX architect always, working out of Detroit, Michigan. Chris is also an instructor, teacher assistant, and volunteer for the Ann Arbor chapter of Girl Develop It and co-organizer for the Ann Arbor Accessibility Group. Chris loves coming up with solutions for enterprise applications, which include modular CSS architectures, performance, and advocating for web accessibility. When he is not working on making the web great and inclusive you can find him writing blog posts, recording episodes of his podcast, Tales From The Script, watching horror movies, drinking the finest of beers, or in the woods of northern Michigan.
title: Focusing on Focus
abstract: When we think of CSS and Accessibility, what comes to mind? Is :focus given that much thought since browser's style these by default? Often, focus outlines are turned off in CSS to meet non-inclusive design standards, but this causes problems for keyboard users.
description:
When we think of CSS and Accessibility, what comes to mind? Is it adding alt attributes to image tags? How about color contrast? Is :focus given that much thought since browser's style these by default? Often, focus outlines are turned off in CSS to meet non-inclusive design standards, but this causes problems for keyboard users. How can we make the web a more inclusive place while maintaining design intent?.

As we build more and more things on the web, we must do our part in building awesome, accessible user experiences. Except native default browser styling of the :focus pseudo class is rather blah, don't you think? There has to be a better way to add some pizzazz to elements when users navigate without a mouse. In this talk, I will demo numerous ways to provide custom focus styles despite known limitations in the web platform. For users with disabilities, it's imperative that visual design finds a way to meet in the middle.
notes:
Past Speaking Engagements

https://youtu.be/UG67_ub8Mag (Cerner Engineering)
https://youtu.be/QvJAAoLdrE0 (StirTrek 2018)
https://youtu.be/g4NY-AUazEI (Swift Kick Show 2018)
https://youtu.be/YefvZJsenFM (IgniteUX MI 2017)

name: Joel Lord
bio:
Joel Lord is passionate about web and technology in general.  He likes to learn new things but most of all, he likes to share his discoveries.  He does so by travelling at various conferences all across the globe.
He graduated from college in computer programming in the last millennium.  Apart for a little break to get his BSc in computational astrophysics, he was always in the industry.
As a technical evangelist with Auth0, he meets with developers to help them make the web a safer place.
During his free time, he is usually found stargazing in a camping site somewhere or brewing a fresh batch of beer in his garage.
title: Forgot Password? Yes I Did!
abstract: Every month, we hear about a new data breach and billions of user passwords are being shared as we speak.  How can we stop this?  There is a simple solution, letâ€™s stop using passwords!  From email links to biometrics, more and more technologies are available to help developers.
description: Every month, we hear about a new data breach and billions of user passwords are being shared as we speak.  How can we stop this?  There is a simple solution, letâ€™s stop using passwords!  From email links to biometrics, more and more technologies are available to help developers handle different types of credentials.  During this presentation, the attendees will learn about some of the alternatives and how to implement them in the context of an OAuth flow.
notes: This talk is a great talk for the end of the day slot when the attendees brains are already full.  While this talk is technical in nature, it focuses on the alternatives to password rather than the actual implementation (although some code is shown).  This makes this talk suitable for any audience.
additional_info: I should be able to get my company to cover expenses, we can discuss once I am accepted :)

name: Chad Green
bio:
Chad Green is a manager, software developer, architect, community leader, and most importantly a father and husband. Chad works as the Data & Solution Architect for ProgressiveHealth where he manages the application development team which is responsible for crafting software solutions for the various company affiliates located across the country, which provides health and wellness solutions in the healthcare and industrial service settings. Over the years, Chad has managed groups from 5 to 63 people and worked on projects in a wide range of markets including healthcare, military, government, workforce management, financial services, chemical research, and electronic commerce.

One of the ways Chad has kept up with technology and development practices is by attending user groups and software development events throughout the country. Being a big believer in giving back and wanting to ensure that there are cool events for other software development professionals, Chad founded and chairs the annual Code PaLOUsa conference, organizes the Louisville .NET Meetup user group and the Monthly Tech Leader Coffee and Discussion, and has helped with other groups like the Louisville Tech Ladies and events like Cincy Day of Agile. Chad also speaks at user groups and conferences about .NET development, VSTS, and leadership.
title: Getting Started with Azure DevOps
abstract: DevOps is about people, process, and products; DevOps is about continually getting better in delivering value to your customers.  Come to this session to learn about Microsoftâ€™s products to bring DevOps goodness to your development process.
description: DevOps is about people, process, and products; DevOps is about continually getting better in delivering value to your customers.  Getting it right requires a lot of effort, but the benefits to your organization and customers are tremendous.  Microsoft has a fantastic set of products that can help you get the most out of the cloud and help in deploying your application to any platform.  In this demo-heavy session, Chad shows you how to go from zero to DevOps and how to being the transformation of your team to a well-oiled machine that is constantly making the customers happy.

name: Vaibhav Gujral
bio: Cloud/Azure Architect â€¢ DevOps Evangelist â€¢ Microsoft Certified Professional â€¢ Speaker
title: Getting started with "Azure DevOps" journey
abstract: Azure DevOps enables IT organizations to plan smarter, collaborate better, and ship faster with a set of modern dev services. This talk will cover basics of Azure DevOps including Azure Pipelines, Azure Repos, Azure Artifacts and Azure Boards. The session will be a mix of slides and demonstrations.
description:
Azure DevOps (formerly known as Visual Studio Team Services) enables IT organizations to plan smarter, collaborate better, and ship faster with a set of modern dev services. This talk will cover basics of Azure DevOps including Azure Pipelines, Azure Repos, Azure Artifacts and Azure Boards. The session will be a mix of slides and demonstrations.

Demos will include setting up end-to-end CI/CD pipelines, managing boards, handling artifacts, managing code repositories, managing branch security, handling pull requests and so on.
notes:
Session Duration - 1 hour
Audience - .Net developers/Cloud developers/Azure developers/architects/software engineers
Requirements - would need internet access and projector
additional_info: I stay at Omaha. So, travel and stay might not be an issue.

name: Chad Green
bio:
Chad Green is a manager, software developer, architect, community leader, and most importantly a father and husband. Chad works as the Data & Solution Architect for ProgressiveHealth where he manages the application development team which is responsible for crafting software solutions for the various company affiliates located across the country, which provides health and wellness solutions in the healthcare and industrial service settings. Over the years, Chad has managed groups from 5 to 63 people and worked on projects in a wide range of markets including healthcare, military, government, workforce management, financial services, chemical research, and electronic commerce.

Being a big believer in giving back and wanting to ensure that there are cool events for other software development professionals, Chad founded and chairs the annual Code PaLOUsa conference, organizes the Louisville .NET Meetup user group and the Monthly Tech Leader Coffee and Discussion, and has helped with other groups like the Louisville Tech Ladies and events like Cincy Day of Agile.
