title: Getting Started with Azure SQL Database
abstract: Are you still hosting your databases on your own SQL Server?  Would you like to consider putting those up in the cloud?  Then come and learn what exactly Azure SQL can do for you and how to go about moving your databases to the cloud.
description:
Azure SQL Database is a cloud-based relationship database service based on Microsoftâ€™s SQL Server engine.  It delivers predictable performance, dynamic scalability, and robust data protection so you can focus on front-end application development rather than managing machines and infrastructure.  SQL Database supports existing SQL Server tools, libraries, and APIs, making it simple to migrate existing database solutions to the cloud and leverage them using skills you already have.  And it features the largest compliance portfolio in the industry, including HIPAA, FERPA, and even Singapore MTCS Level 3.

During this session, you will learn the features and benefits of Azure SQL Database.  There will also be demonstrations of how to create an Azure SQL Database and populate data into it.  We will create an Azure API App to expose the database securely to clients using REST calls, create a Universal Windows Platform app to access the database through the API App, and use security features of SQL database to limit the information returned.

name: Steven Hicks
bio:
Steven Hicks is a software engineer with nearly 20 years experience. He believes that code is for humans, and should be written with them in mind. Steve likes to use the right tool for the job, especially if the right tool is JavaScript. He strongly believes that if you ain't falling, you ain't learning. 

Steve embraces continuous improvement and believes that a developer's job is to solve problems, not just write code. He is a speaker, a writer, a teacher, a learner, and a teammate.

When he isn't talking to the duck or crushing 1s and 0s, you can find Steve outside. He's probably camping with his family, racing a triathlon, running trails, or climbing fake rocks.
title: Getting Unstuck
abstract:
Even with the simplest of problems, we can get stuck. The key to success as a developer is knowing how to get yourself unstuck.

We'll look at strategies for breaking through when you've hit an impenetrable wall. These strategies will help you understand and isolate the problem, and move on.
description:
You've followed along with the docs. Everything seems like it should be working. You've looked over this code 20 times, but you can't figure out why it's not working. You're frustrated, and you're ready to give up.

Even with the simplest of problems, we can get stuck. It happens to all of us - to new hires and senior engineers alike. The key to success as a developer is knowing how to get yourself unstuck.

We'll look at several strategies for breaking through when it seems like you've hit an impenetrable wall. These strategies will help you understand, explain, and isolate the problem. Most importantly, they'll help you move on.

Getting unstuck is a skill. This session will help you sharpen that skill, and prepare you for the next time you hit a wall.
notes:
Hearing someone tell me in a standup that they are stuck on something is like a bat-signal to me. My eyes light up, and I drop everything I'm working on to help them get past it. I'd love to share my strategies with your audience.

I will be giving this talk for the first time at CodeMash in Ohio in January, 2019.

Outline of strategies:

### Explain The Problem

#### Talk to the duck

#### Talk to a person

#### Pair with a person

#### Write up an email/Slack message/StackOverflow post describing the problem

### Isolate The Problem

#### Remove code (binary search)

#### Back out changes iteratively

#### Build a proof-of-concept

#### Extract functions & unit test them

### Escape The Problem

#### Relax (Go for a walk, take a shower, go to bed...)

#### Physical Exercise

#### Other hobbies

#### Move on to another problem

name: Kelly Andrews
bio:
Kelly J Andrews is a developer advocate and has been tinkering with computers for over 30 years, using BASIC for the first time at the age of 5.

 It wasn't until building his first webpage in 1997, and trying out JavaScript for the first time that he found a true calling. Kelly now fights for JavaScript, testable code, and fast delivery. 

In his free time you can find him singing karaoke, performing magic, or cheering for the Fighting Irish.
title: Give In To The Bot Overlords
abstract: Chatbots are an amazing tool that allows you to automate the tasks that you find yourself doing on a daily basis.
description:
Chatbots are an amazing tool that allows you to automate the tasks that you find yourself doing on a daily basis.  

A good Chatbot can manage tasks that don't require human involvement and reduce the amount of overhead required in different processes.  As an integrated part of your overall ChatOps tactics, it can improve many different facets, and reduce overall workloads. 

Empowering people to do their jobs is a powerful strategy for any team.  Reducing bottlenecks, streamlining processes, and automating tasks can lead to increases in job satisfaction and team productivity. 

This talk will give you some ideas on how to use bots, a quick overview of how to get started, and provide some inspiration on what your team can do to improve its ChatOps strategy.
notes:
Chatbots are a great way for any development or DevOps team to automate tasks that typically fall on one or two people. Building them can seem daunting, but once you get going it's a great way to improve the overall workflow. 

In this talk I will be sure to cover the following:

+ Various ideas on how you can use a bot (repo creation, API actions, CI/CD, stats/reports) 
+ Overview of how you can get started building a ChatBot inside Slack using Botkit
+ Some cloud tools that can help - language processing as one example

Based on my initial blog post here - https://dev.to/kellyjandrews/using-slack-and-chatops-to-create-new-projects-4bag
additional_info: No travel assistance is required :)

name: Patrick Wolff
bio: Patrick is passionate about collaboration, human computer interaction, graphic design and problem solving. His degree in Digital Imaging from the University of Nebraska at Omaha led him down a career path that includes television, advertising, Flash development for online learning, web development, enterprise application development, Geographic Information Systems, and leadership. Currently, Patrick serves as VP of Applications Development at Farm Credit Services of America.
title: Grow The Future With Internship 2.0
abstract: Farm Credit Services of America has developed an Intern Program that pushes students' learning into warp speed. Software students learn the full suite of modern professional skills: culture, teamwork, collaboration, and tech. It's like a summer skills camp for soon-to-be professional developers!
description:
Farm Credit Services of America has a different take on what an Internship experience should be. We took the idea of an Internship, and made it AWESOME! The Intern Program is team based, and allows a small group of software development students to work together on a team along with four or five full-time mentors and leaders to create a greenfield enterprise application. The experience allows the students to iterate through the full software development life cycle in an enterprise environment: from sketching out wire-frames to deploying an enterprise application in Production. 

We will also talk through how we do our intern interviews differently. Our interviews do not consist of the traditional sit-down interview with questions. We have a fun and relaxed process that let's the candidates express their creativity, collaboration, problem solving, and their personality. This helps to insure that we are investing in people that fit our culture.

One of the greatest benefits to our approach is that the students get an experience of what life is like in the real world. The amount of learning that happens when you apply the theory that's been learned in school across the entirety of the software development life-cycle in highly-collaborative enterprise team environment is indescribable.
notes: We are the best people to talk on this subject, because we don't think there's another company around that has an Intern Program designed in this way. The feedback we get from the interns that have experienced our internship, and other internships at well-known technology companies is that ours is second to none. We continue to attract top talent, and our recruitment base grows year-after-year by word-of-mouth from the students. We've also hired many of our interns into full-time positions after they graduate.

name: Chris DeMars
bio: Chris DeMars is a UI developer first, UX architect always, working out of Detroit, Michigan. Chris is also an instructor, teacher assistant, and volunteer for the Ann Arbor chapter of Girl Develop It and co-organizer for the Ann Arbor Accessibility Group. Chris loves coming up with solutions for enterprise applications, which include modular CSS architectures, performance, and advocating for web accessibility. When he is not working on making the web great and inclusive you can find him writing blog posts, recording episodes of his podcast, Tales From The Script, watching horror movies, drinking the finest of beers, or in the woods of northern Michigan.
title: Hacking the Human Perception
abstract: Hacking you say? Yes, I d, but this type of hacking involves how we as developers, create the illusion of fast load times for our Web applications. This talk will focus on ways we can make things appear to be faster than they are and ways to avoid having to play Houdini entirely.
description: Hacking you say? Yes, I do, but this type of hacking has nothing to do with hooking in Matrix style or surfing through The Gibson at Ellingson Mineral Company. Nope, this type of hacking involves how we as developers, create the illusion of fast load times for our Web applications. Performance is gaining much visibility in the industry and catering to the needs of the user, there are many things we can do to facilitate that need. This talk will focus on ways we can make things appear to be faster than they are and ways to avoid having to play Houdini entirely.
notes:
Past Speaking Engagements

https://youtu.be/UG67_ub8Mag (Cerner Engineering)
https://youtu.be/QvJAAoLdrE0 (StirTrek 2018)
https://youtu.be/g4NY-AUazEI (Swift Kick Show 2018)
https://youtu.be/YefvZJsenFM (IgniteUX MI 2017)

name: Cam Soper
bio:
While in high school, Cam was getting paid for writing code and playing jazz (but not necessarily at the same time!). After flirting with several career paths in college, he decided to stick with what he knew.

Cam's development and IT career began in 1991 when a small town computer consultant took Cam, then 12 years old, as his apprentice. After graduating from Missouri State University in 1999, Cam worked as a trainer, adjunct professor, and freelance developer until he took a full-time developer job in the financial services industry in 2000.

In 2012, Cam achieved his childhood dream of joining Microsoft as a travelling support engineer, where he helped companies and public institutions of all sizes deploy software for .NET and Azure. He is currently part of the Microsoft APEX (Azure Platform Evangelism and Experiences) team, where he writes content about Azure and .NET on docs.microsoft.com, including reference applications and samples. 

Cam lives in Kansas City, Missouri, USA with his wife, three sons, two dogs, two cats, three guinea pigs, and two hermit crabs. His hobbies include video games, 3D printing, home automation, and creating music.
title: Have Your Pi and Eat It Too: .NET Core on Raspberry Pi
abstract: The open source, cross-platform design of .NET Core opens up all kinds of new possibilities for .NET developers. This talk teaches the attendee how to install the .NET Core runtime on the ultimate IoT platform, Raspberry Pi and unlock the potential of IoT devices for .NET developers!
description:
Is .NET your jam? Are you berry interested in development on Linux? Think developing code for IoT devices is just Pi in the sky? In this (hopefully) pun-free (but not *fun*-free!) session, you'll watch Pi-eyed as we demonstrate possibilities of .NET Core, including ASP.NET Core and Web API, on a device the size of a credit card!

You'll learn:

* How to configure your Raspberry Pi for .NET Core
* Building, deploying, and running .NET Core apps on Raspberry Pi
* Accessing the hardware of the Raspberry Pi from .NET Core code
notes:
I'm a docs developer on the .NET team at Microsoft. I don't have any extraordinary tech requirements beyond an HDMI connection for the presentation and, preferably, good internet connectivity. 

[This talk was presented for .NET Conf 2018 here](https://channel9.msdn.com/Events/dotnetConf/2018/S314).

[My slides, notes, and demos are here](https://github.com/CamSoper/have-your-pi).

name: Harold Schreckengost
bio: I work for CrossBrowserTesting doing DevOps and architecture, and live in Memphis, where I spend a lot of time working with the Memphis Technology Foundation community.
title: Hiring for (Meaningful) Diversity
abstract: There's a lot of talk now about diversity, and that's a really great thing - but why do we care about diversity?  What's the business case for diversity - if there is one (spoiler: there is!) - and how can businesses begin hiring for meaningful diversity?
description: There's a lot of talk now about diversity, and that's a really great thing - but why do we care about diversity?  What's the business case for diversity - and how can businesses begin hiring for meaningful diversity?

name: Greg Dick
bio: I'm a Senior Engineering Team Lead at Hudl. My role as a team lead could be more accurately described as a coach. I have a passion for helping people, and I take that into my management role in form of coaching my reports to become better engineers, finding the best ways to motivate them, and providing them with authentic connections and meaningful relationships.
title: How Hudl Successfully Integrates Remote Employees
abstract: Hudl's product team is spread across 5 different offices throughout the world and we have many purely remote employees. In the beginning, we felt the pains of distributed teams, but we've found great solutions to keep our teams working efficiently and to keep those remote employees engaged.
description:
This presentation covers many of the strategies Hudl has used for creating distributed teams where members aren't working in the same office. We consider ourselves to have a strong and thriving remote culture. We have tried many things over the past 4 years, and I'll be sharing what worked and what didn't. For our company and many others, remote employees are essential to growing the company due to a limited talent pool in one area. The challenges involved with engaging and retaining those employees can be a big hindrance to that growth. The goal of this talk is to help other companies that may be testing the waters or struggling with remote employees and distributed teams.

Some of these strategies are around holding meetings in a way that don't leave remote people at a disadvantage, keeping _all_ team communication in a medium that includes remote people, and scheduling explicit pair programming time with remote people. Everyone gets a webcam and a quality headset, and we focus on making sure there's plenty of bandwidth for everyone to be on video chats. We've removed as much friction as possible to keep our employees engaged with each other despite being a thousand miles away.
notes: While I am not a remote employee, I have been on and involved with distributed teams with remote employees for years. I was there when we first started experimenting with ways to maintain efficiency with distributed teams as well as ways to keep remote employees engaged with the company. When on distributed teams, I've been a driver in changing our processes to make a better experience for remote workers. Employee engagement and retention has always been a passion of mine, so I've paid close attention to what has worked, what hasn't, and why.

name: Cam Soper
bio:
While in high school, Cam was getting paid for writing code and playing jazz (but not necessarily at the same time!). After flirting with several career paths in college, he decided to stick with what he knew.

Cam's development and IT career began in 1991 when a small town computer consultant took Cam, then 12 years old, as his apprentice. After graduating from Missouri State University in 1999, Cam worked as a trainer, adjunct professor, and freelance developer until he took a full-time developer job in the financial services industry in 2000.

In 2012, Cam achieved his childhood dream of joining Microsoft as a travelling support engineer, where he helped companies and public institutions of all sizes deploy software for .NET and Azure. He is currently part of the Microsoft APEX (Azure Platform Evangelism and Experiences) team, where he writes content about Azure and .NET on docs.microsoft.com, including reference applications and samples. 

Cam lives in Kansas City, Missouri, USA with his wife, three sons, two dogs, two cats, three guinea pigs, and two hermit crabs. His hobbies include video games, 3D printing, home automation, and creating music.
title: How Insightful! Grok Your ASP.NET Core Web Apps with Application Insights
abstract: Azure Application Insights provides deep profiling and tracing information for any ASP.NET application with very little configuration at no cost. Every production ASP.NET Core app can be instrumented with App Insights at no cost, whether hosted on-premise or in the cloud!
description:
You know the feeling. An executive sends that email that your web application's performance is costing sales. All hands on deck! Fix it now! Your future is now hours poring over log files, days guessing where the bottleneck is. You hope for success with each new deployment. There's a different path. Application Insights to the rescue!Â  Instrument your app with Application Insights to get a deep look into the performance profile of your on-premise or Azure-hosted app. Prevent bottlenecks before you get that "all hands on deck" email.

You will learn:

* What telemetry Application Insights collects automatically
* How to instrument your ASP.NET Core application with custom events and metrics
* How to view and analyze the telemetry using Azure's powerful tools
notes:
I'm a docs developer on the .NET team at Microsoft. I don't have any extraordinary tech requirements beyond an HDMI connection for the presentation and, preferably, good internet connectivity.

[My slides and notes for this talk can be found here](https://github.com/CamSoper/how-insightful).

name: Baskar Rao DSN
bio:
I have zeal to learn new technologies and share the same from my experience. With over 10 years of experience developing software applications and designing solutions , I solve complex problems faced by enterprise applications on a day to day basis.  Am technologist and try to keep myself updated with latest technology advancements. I regularly attend Microsoft events and actively participate in meetup groups.
Am a good listener and feel that I can easily communicate my thoughts and convince the group on my ideas.
title: How to make developer life easy to implement Authentication Solutions for your Enterprise
abstract: As a developer we always feel challenged when we are tasked to implement authentication and authorization based solutions. These concepts though they seem simple, it requires huge amount of responsibility within the team which manages authentication solutions. Shifting to cloud based solution helps.
description:
It is always an overwhelming task for a developer to understand the different authentication providers and keep track of changes happening with each authentication platform.
 Different social login providers have different implementations of the protocols and authentication mechanism. Maintaining code base specific to each token issuers would be a nightmare 
 if one has to support multiple providers. This is where a cloud based authentication solution is helpful to developers reducing the amount of time required to develop enterprise applications.
 In this talk we will explore the different use cases that can be implemented using Auth0 platform and understand the basics of the platform to get started. 
 Developers will be able to understand the key concepts which they can use in their regular day to day development tasks. 
 A demo will be conducted using web application developed using Vue Js and mobile application using NativeScript

name: Joel Lord
bio:
Joel Lord is passionate about web and technology in general.  He likes to learn new things but most of all, he likes to share his discoveries.  He does so by travelling at various conferences all across the globe.
He graduated from college in computer programming in the last millennium.  Apart for a little break to get his BSc in computational astrophysics, he was always in the industry.
As a technical evangelist with Auth0, he meets with developers to help them make the web a safer place.
During his free time, he is usually found stargazing in a camping site somewhere or brewing a fresh batch of beer in his garage.
title: I Don't Care About Security (And Neither Should You)
abstract: Remember that time where setting up a login page was easy?  It seems like nowadays, it take many days to start a project just to create a signup form, a login form and a forget password screen.  Thankfully, there are tools to help us avoid dealing with all of this.  This is what you will learn here.
description: Remember that time where setting up a login page was easy?  It seems like nowadays, it take many weeks to start a project just to create a signup form, a login form and a forget password screen.  And that is if you donâ€™t need 2 factor authentication or passwordless authentication.  During this presentation, the attendees will be introduced to OpenID and OAuth.  They will also learn how to leverage this to create secure application or, most importantly, how to delegate to a third party so they can focus on their real work.
additional_info: I should be able to get my company to cover expenses, we can discuss once I am accepted :)

name: Leon Stigter
bio: Leon Stigter is a Developer Advocate at TIBCO Software, where he creates tools and technologies to help drive the (r)evolution of digital business. Leon is passionate about helping developers unlock the value of their technology by helping to shape the developer experience and ecosystem around the Open Source projects at TIBCO.
title: I know what you deployed last summer!
abstract: We all deploy many services and we forget where they are and how to invoke them. With 2 services that is easy to handle, but what about 20? Keeping track of them and keeping the docs in sync is tough! Join Leon Stigter to find out how to deploy services and remember what you deployed last summer
description:
As a Developer Advocate, I get to talk to lots of developers. Two major topics that keep coming up are, "_where did I deploy that microservice?_" and "_what is the API definition of that microservice again?_". 

When your deployment footprint on Kubernetes grows, maintaining all those deployed services on can become a challenge. Keeping the API documentation up-to-date for developers can make it all the more challenging. 

In this session, we'll build some microservices, deploy them to Kubernetes, and at the same time keep track of where they are and their API specifications (much wow). And the best part? We'll only use OSS :)

name: Jesse Sanders
bio: Jesse Sanders is the founder and CEO of BrieBug and a Google Developer Expert (GDE) in Angular and Web Technologies. He regularly speaks around the world on Angular and related web technologies to inform and inspire developers on how to build the next generation of web applications. He regularly teaches workshops on Angular fundamentals, NgRx, and advanced Angular topics. He specializes in architecting systems using Angular for enterprise clients to help them achieve their goals. When not working, he enjoys spending time with his children, biking, skiing/snowboarding, hiking, and training for triathlons. You can follow him on twitter - @JesseS_BrieBug
title: I'm so done with E2E testing... until now.
abstract:
E2E has always been a problem. Tests take too long to run and fail intermittently for no reason. This leads many developers to quickly ditch E2E test.

Introducing Cypress; a new tool for E2E tests that makes E2E simple and consistent.  In 60 minutes you'll learn why its your new go to for testing.
description:
Testing applications from end to end (E2E) has always been a difficult proposition. Whether you've tried Selenium, Webdriver, Protractor, Nightwatch, or similar tool, this type of testing is unproductive. The tests take too long to run and fail intermittently for no apparent reason. It's difficult to test features of an application without spending lots of time setting up "magic data" scenarios so we can verify that each aspect our application works as expected. This arduous process leads many developers to frustration and a to quickly ditch E2E on their projects

No More!

Introducing Cypress.io, a new way of doing E2E tests that makes testing incredibly simple and easy to manage. Cypress allows developers to focus on what's important and get the results we want without having to jump through a bunch of hoops. We will be exploring what Cypress.io has to offer, how to set it up, and how it will change how you look at E2E tests.
notes: I'm a regular speaker at meetups around the country and have spoke at Angular Mix, Ng-Cong, Angular Up (Tel Aviv) this past year.  I am an experience developer trainer and have conducted multiple workshops helping developers learn from 0 to zero in just two days.  You can find videos of me regularly on YouTube speaking at meetups and conferences.
additional_info: I have family in the area, was born and raised in Omaha until I was about 10 years old, and I will also cover my own travel expenses to get there.  I am also the organizer for Angular Denver, a first year, 200+ attendee conference we held this past August.  We held a successful conference and would be willing to do what we can to help you to be successful and learn from our experience, regardless if you choose me as a speaker.

name: Dustin Collins
bio: Interactive artist and automation engineer. Interested in the cultures and tools that enable high-performing teams and organizations.
title: Inside Attacker: An Overview
abstract: For this presentation I'll cover what the term 'inside attacker'. What does it mean and what are the stats? Are inside attacks getting worse or better? If worse, what can we do about that?
description:
In this talk I want to debunk the myth of the inside attacker. The cybersecurity industry tends to use language that alienates people and buries serious problems. 'Inside attacker' is just another example of this. 

At the end of the talk the audience will have: an overview of the history of the term 'inside attacker', how it is commonly used in industry, the problem with using that term and some remediation strategies.
notes:
I spoke about this in a shorter format at DevOpsDays Kansas City 2017.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ReuepsVYRq4

I'd like the opportunity to dig more into the topic and share what I know with your audience.

name: Jamie Wright
bio: Jamie Wright is a maker of internet things with a love/hate relationship for Redbullâ„¢, standing desks, and paintball guns. He has a love only relationship with teaching, learning, and building bots. Jamie runs Tatsu, a software bot that helps teams save time by performing standup meetings over Slack.
title: Introducing Juvet: Building Bots in Elixir
abstract: Designing chatbots will soon be an essential skill that all developers should know. Chat will at the very least an extension of the existing services their apps provide or the sole platform and at the most, the sole way users interact with our applications.
description:
There is another massive shift happening with how we interact with companies through software. Users feel comfortable naturally talking with their applications through chat bots. Chat is the next generation of the user interface.

Companies like Slack, Facebook, WhatsApp, and WeChat have some of the most popular apps in the world and they are all betting on a messaging interface.

Elixir is the perfect language and ecosystem for building bots and for conversational interfaces. In this session, we will see how we can build scalable, realtime web applications (or â€œbotsâ€) using a new library Juvet and the Slack API. We will see what a good bot architecture looks like and how we can integrate with existing artificial intelligence services to make our bots smarter.
notes:
The theme of the talk is around chatbots, specifically why they are important in software development, what makes a good chatbot in terms of UI considerations, design, and architecture.

For the other half of the talk, I would like to introduce a new OSS project that allows developers to easily build bots in Elixir. We will talk about why we should be building bots in Elixir and reviewing key implementations for connecting your bot, chat, conversations, and natural language processing.

name: Bill Dinger
bio:
Bill is a Solutions Architect with VML working on delivering digital solutions to our clients. Over the last 15 years Bill has worked in enterprise IT starting in the trenches on the help desk. After that, Bill spent almost a decade working in infrastructure support focusing in the Microsoft stack. Over the last 5 years Bill has been developing, architecting and leading teams of software developers with VML. During that time Bill has done everything from troubleshoot dial up connections in rural Nebraska to building the digital experiences for some of America's most well known brands.

When not working, Bill will probably be found on his bike exploring gravel roads in his hometown of Lincoln, Nebraska.
title: Introduction to Asynchronous Code in .NET
abstract: In this beginner level talk we'll go over the common asynchronous patterns available in .NET. We'll focus on the Thread Parallel Library (TPL), Parallel Linq (PLINQ) and the new async/await keywords introduced in .NET 4.5.  We'll discuss when to use these patterns and when not to.
description: This talk will focus on the basics of the thread parallel library, the async/await keywords, and PLINQ (parallel LINQ).  We'll offer an explanation of when to use each method in the real world, the possible pitfalls to using each, and various tips to a successful implementation. We will also go over the general benefits of asynchronous code to user's application and the types of benefits they can expect to see. Finally, attendees will be warned of ways to avoid deadlocks and performance issues when using asynchronous .NET code as well as the basics of debugging asynchronous code.
notes:
I've been writing & using asynchronous code ever since it came out for .NET in 2012. In addition to implementing it in the real world in various scenarios including asp.net web api, console, & service projects , I've attended numerous talks on the subject at various tech conferences. I've also helped resolve a number of real life deadlock and performance issues caused by poorly implemented asynchronous code.

This talk has been given at DevUp, Detroit.Code(), Prairie.Code() and KCDC.

name: Gabriel Bianconi
bio:
Gabriel is a machine learning scientist with experience in applying cutting-edge academic research to solve real-world problems.

He began his training as a B.S. & M.S. student in computer science at Stanford University, where he received multiple academic distinctions, including the President's Award for Academic Excellence.

He was one of ten students to graduate with honors in computer science in his undergraduate class at Stanford. His thesis investigated quantum deep learning algorithms using NASA's D-Wave quantum computer, and was selected for a presentation at the AQC 2017 Conference in Tokyo, Japan.

During his master's program, he conducted research at the Stanford Partnership in AI-Assisted Care, a joint lab between the Stanford Computer Science Department (Prof. Fei-Fei Li â€“ Chief Scientist of Cloud AI/ML at Google) and the Stanford School of Medicine (Prof. Arnold Milstein). His research focused on improving clinical care and reducing monitoring costs in hospitals by leveraging machine learning and computer vision, and resulted in a first-author manuscript selected as Top 10 Research Paper at the NIPS Machine Learning for Health 2017 Workshop.

Gabriel also has extensive software engineering experience. At Google and Facebook, he worked on backend infrastructure for enterprise tools responsible for billions of dollars in revenue. He's also created an advertising supply-side platform that handled millions of ad requests per day, built an algorithmic trading platform and quantitative strategies for cryptoasset markets that handled over US$10M in volume, and held positions at startups and investment firms.
title: Introduction to Face Processing with Computer Vision
abstract:
Ever wonder how Facebookâ€™s facial recognition or Snapchatâ€™s filters work?

In this talk, weâ€™ll help you understand some of the computer vision and machine learning techniques behind these applications, and use this knowledge to develop our own prototypes for the products above.
description:
*Ever wonder how Facebookâ€™s facial recognition or Snapchatâ€™s filters work?*

Faces are a fundamental piece of photography, and building applications around them has never been easier with open-source libraries and pre-trained models.

In this talk, weâ€™ll help you understand some of the computer vision and machine learning techniques behind these applications. Then, weâ€™ll use this knowledge to develop our own prototypes to tackle tasks such as face detection (e.g. digital cameras), recognition (e.g. Facebook Photos), classification (e.g. identifying emotions), manipulation (e.g. Snapchat filters), and more.
notes:
Target Audience: Technical audience. Basic knowledge of machine learning and Python is helpful but not required.

Author: The author is a machine learning scientist focused on computer vision, and has experience in giving technical talks to large audiences.

Note: The code examples and libraries in the talk are in Python.

name: Thomas Cleberg
title: Introduction to Probabilistic Programming in Python
abstract: Machine learning often gets the reputation of being opaque, but thatâ€™s not always the case. In this talk, we review the basics of probabilistic programming in Python and explore the many-armed bandit problem.
description: Machine learning often gets the reputation of being opaque, but thatâ€™s not always the case. In this talk, we review the basics of probabilistic programming in Python and explore the many-armed bandit problem to demonstrate how it can be used for continuous and extremely transparent machine learning applications.

name: Billy Korando
bio: Billy is a developer advocate with IBM and has over a decade of experience. Billy is passionate about finding ways to reduce mental capacity waste from tedious work; such as project initation, deployment, testing and validation, and so on through automation and good management practices. Outside of work Billy enjoy traveling, playing kickball, and having his heartbroken by cheering on the Kansas City Chiefs.
title: JUnit 5 the Next Step in Automated Testing for Java
abstract: JUnit 5 has been out for a year, so what is the big fuss and why should I take the time to update my existing automated tests to use JUnit 5? In this presentation we will look at many of the new features that have been added in JUnit 5 over the past year.
description: JUnit 5 has been out for a year, so what is the big fuss and why should I take the time to update my existing automated tests to use JUnit 5? In this presentation we will look at many of the new features that have been added in JUnit 5 and not only how they make automated testing easier, but allow developers to write tests in ways that were difficult or impossible to do before. If you have been wondering why you should make the switch from JUnit 4 to JUnit 5 you will definitely want to check out this presentation.
notes:
I have presented on JUnit 5 extensively, including LavaOne, DevNexus 2018, Spring IO, and other conferences and user groups. I have also written a number of blog articles on automated testing, including JUnit 5 Links to previous presentations and blog articles below:

Welcome to JUnit 5 @ LavaOne: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CC2ZdESKZNM   

Blog series on automated testing: https://keyholesoftware.com/category/series/automatedtestingseries/
https://medium.com/@BillyKorando

A major goal of this presentation will be looking at how the new features in JUnit 5 will allow developers and organizations to do things with automated testing that weren't possible before. A good example of this I cover in this blog article: https://keyholesoftware.com/2018/02/06/encouraging-good-behavior-with-junit-5-test-interfaces/

name: Chris Holland
bio: Chris Holland leads a small Software Engineering Team at an HR company. Throughout a career spanning more than 20 years, Chris has held Sr. Engineering and Leadership roles for small and large successful publicly-traded companies such as EarthLink and Internet Brands, serving business models across Content, Commerce, Travel & Finance on a wide variety of technology stacks including PHP/LAMP, Java/J2EE and C#/.Net, catering to audiences over 100 million monthly visitors.
title: Keynote:  Taming Change
abstract: Change is Software's greatest threat, *and* its defining characteristic. Disagree? How's that Agile Transformation going for you?
description:
Change is Software's greatest threat, *and* its defining characteristic. Disagree? How's that Agile Transformation going for you?

We will explore this cognitively-dissonant statement as we investigate the challenges that we've faced, how we continue to fail to address them, and what we can do tame this raucous beast.
notes:
As of this writing, this Keynote has never been given.

It will essentially contain many of the elements of this article: [http://bit.ly/change-in-software](http://bit.ly/change-in-software)

name: Tejas Kumar
bio: I love code. I love people. I love talking to people about code! I've been programming since I was 8, and currently lead a front-end development team in Berlin, Germany. I love what I do and I enjoy talking about it around the world.
title: Let's Talk WebAssembly
abstract: WebAssembly is a hot topic in the web development world. This talk aims to provide insights into what it is, how it can be used, and what it entails for the future of the Web and Native platforms. There will be live coding.
description:
This talk aims to closely examine WebAssembly, an emerging technology on the Web Platform allowing the execution of low-level machine code in the browser. The reason for this talk is that these technologies are interesting to most front-end engineers and have a lot of potential for building the future of the Web Platform.

We will even include a live coding session, where we will, together, build a WebAssembly module that shares code with JavaScript in the browser.

Introduction

- JavaScript

  - History of JavaScript

  - JavaScript of Today

  - JavaScript is Portable



  - WebAssembly

    - What is WebAssembly?

    - Why WebAssembly?

    - How can we write and work with WebAssembly today?

- Rust

  - History of Rust

  - Rust Basics: syntax, ownership, etc.

- Live coding! Let's write a library in Rust (C), and

  - compile it to WebAssembly, and

    - run in in the browser!

- Conclusion

  - By now, everyone should have a working knowledge and understanding of WebAssembly.

name: Harshinee Sriram
bio:
If there is something that is consistent with nature and life, it is pattern, symmetry, and the fluidic passing of infinite moments. Ever since I was a little girl, I was drawn to creating something that resonates with all that life is about. Be it music, dance, art, or advancement. My music and writing taught me to be observant, tactile, and to dream. My dance helped me understand vulnerabilities, touch, and confidence. And, my Computer Science education taught me to believe in the seemingly impossible and to create something that is beautiful, helpful, and in harmony with the picturesque series of fleeting moments that we call the Human Life. 

Do contact me if you would like to discuss the abstract, the unique, and the revolutionary over a cup of cranberry tea and the Marvel Cinematic Universe (read: definitely the Guardians of the Galaxy).
organization: SRM Institute of Science and Technology, and Aakash Research Labs -IIT Bombay
title: Machine Learning and Artificial Intelligence for Mental Health and Well-Being
abstract: Above all man-made walls, humans quite similar. We embrace the warm sunlight after a harsh winter, we yearn to be loved, and we wish to be helped in times of need. I aspire to explain how Artificial Intelligence can help all of us by contributing to mental health, one python expression at a time.
description:
In 2013, the Veteran Affairs (VA) released a study that covered suicides from 1999 to 2010, which depicted that roughly 22 veterans were dying by suicide every single day. Some of the possible causes were: longer times at war, brain/head trauma, and seeing other soldiers around them killed. In another study, it was showcased that the rate of suicides in India has risen by 23% from 2000 to 2015, and suicides by young adults is a growing concern in the country. The array of causes includes financial instability, dowry, loan repayment, and caste-related violence.

Depression is one of the leading causes of suicides, and more than 300 million people of all ages worldwide suffer from it. Also, with each passing day, addiction kills 29 people in the United States, due to drunk driving accidents, resulting in the annual cost of alcohol-related crashes to be more than USD 44 billion. Moreover, the National Institute on Drug Abuse (NIH) released the statistics which show that from 2002 to 2017, there was a 3.1-fold increase in the total number of deaths due to drug overdose.

This talk aims to highlight the fact that it is of utmost importance to find solutions for mental disorders in order to help those in need and to abolish all taboos pertaining to identifying traits of a mental illness and subsequently seeking help for the same. The talk will include information regarding the current research in the field of â€œArtificial Intelligence and Machine Learning for Mental Healthâ€ and its ultimate potential. It will also provide several ideas that can be utilized to begin the listenerâ€™s very own project or study via referencing the past projects of the speaker. Moreover, the talk aims to inspire both novices and experts to create something that can benefit the human race, save lives, and to spread the message that every person matters and is deserving of help, irrespective of all boundaries.
notes:
Technical requirements:

  • HDMI cable (or)
  • Ethernet cable

Why I am the best person to speak on this subject:

  • I am a depression and self-harm survivor (suffered from depression for more than 6 years), and thus, I understand the subject area deeply and intricately.
  • I am currently conducting research on the same subject area and have created 2 Machine Learning projects (1. Project TunnelEnd and 2. Eunoia) as a result.
  • I am a co-author of an Indian bestseller anthology titled "Pandora's Box - Horn OK Please". My story revolves around having hope and believing that there is a way out.

name: Matt Hoover
bio: Matt Hoover is a an enthusiastic data aficionado of 5 years who enjoys visualizing data both professionally and for fun. After a brief stint as an analyst at a Fortune 500 company, Matt's career pivoted into data science when he joined CAN as lead consultant for data visualization. While at CAN, Matt helped start the Omaha Data Science Academy where he taught multiple courses on how to use Tableau to visualize data. In early 2018 Matt joined Flywheel, a managed Wordpress hosting company, as a data scientist on the operations team. At Flywheel, Matt is broadly responsible for making the company more data informed. This involves both analyzing Flywheelâ€™s day to day financial and operational data and training people from all departments on how they can use data to do their jobs better. When not analyzing data you'll find Matt running long distances and organizing below average teams in various sports leagues across Omaha.
title: Making Design Matter in the Data Workflow
abstract: The concept of design is often an afterthought in traditional data workflows & BI reporting. At Flywheel, design is the last step in our data flow.  Adding a few elements of design can be the difference between an unused report graveyard and reports that the whole company trusts and checks daily.
description:
One of our core company values at Flywheel is being data informed. As such, our key company reports are shown not only to our executives and board but are also openly shared with the entire company. How do we properly build such far reaching reports that consider many people of varying job titles and data literacy levels? This is where another one of our core values comes in - we believe that design matters.

With such a wide audience, Flywheel's key business reports need to be well designed and engaging so that they can effectively build empathy and ownership across the company on many levels. By adding design as the last step of our data workflow, we ensure that the data everyone sees is unified and familiar; whimsical yet authoritative.

I'll talk about Flywheel's journey making these delightful dashboards as well as demo some useful techniques on how you too can effectively implement design elements into your reporting. Youâ€™ll leave this session knowing how you can enhance both buy-in and trust into your company's reporting by making it feel more familiar and approachable. Design shouldn't just be for designers.
additional_info: N/A

name: Ivan ÄŒuljak
bio: Ivan is a .NET freelance developer in love with Azure, Xamarin, and the idea of automating whatever. When heâ€™s not developing something new, heâ€™s salvaging something inherited, consulting with enthusiasm, and testing and breaking new technologies in a quest for something useful.
title: Making the cloud event-driven, and orchestrated
abstract:
Serverless to me is like an addiction... it keeps bringing me deeper, and deeper down the rabbit hole, so I keep finding problems that I never knew existed, and well... I keep finding solutions to them :)
If you wanna know what awaits you down the serverless road and how to tackle it come and enjoy
description:
Years have passed since serverless started being a hype. Tensions are lowered now, weâ€™ve learned a lot in the mid time, weâ€™ve figured out what for is serverless useful, and how to use it, but weâ€™ve also figured out what are we missing, at least out-of-the-box.

One of the things we are/were missing is the ability to react on a broad spectrum of events in the same way, whether weâ€™re talking abut a click on a web page, a message between parts of our system, an information that a virtual machine has spun up, or even that our credit card has bouncedâ€¦

The other major pain is/was chaining of serverless functions, keeping track what, and where failed, decently handle errors, basicallyâ€¦ having the whole system make us proud, instead of looking like something that MacGyver patched up during a single episode to flee from some narco boss.

Azure gave us EventGrid to solve the first pain while allowing us to event react to inter-cloud events, and weâ€™ve got Durable Functions to orchestrate whatever we feel like.

The goal of this talk is to give you an overview what can you expect when you start playing with serverless more seriously, as to give you some advices how to make your serverless architecture more serious, more stable, and less demanding to constantly watch over your e-mail to see if something has crashed, and degraded.
If you want to hear stories from 18 months of serverless â€œtrenchesâ€, please join.

name: Steven Hicks
bio:
Steven Hicks is a software engineer with nearly 20 years experience. He believes that code is for humans, and should be written with them in mind. Steve likes to use the right tool for the job, especially if the right tool is JavaScript. He strongly believes that if you ain't falling, you ain't learning. 

Steve embraces continuous improvement and believes that a developer's job is to solve problems, not just write code. He is a speaker, a writer, a teacher, a learner, and a teammate.

When he isn't talking to the duck or crushing 1s and 0s, you can find Steve outside. He's probably camping with his family, racing a triathlon, running trails, or climbing fake rocks.
title: Maximize Professional Growth By Doing Scary Things
abstract:
Fear has lost its value. What once saved us from being eaten by saber-toothed tigers now prevents us from realizing our goals. 

In this session, we'll ask questions about the nature of fear. We'll stare fear in the eyes, and look in unusual places to find strategies for overcoming it.
description:
If it wasn't for fear, we'd all have been eaten by saber-toothed tigers when we wandered too far from our caves. 

But fear has lost its value. Fear now spends less time saving our lives, and more time preventing us from realizing our goals. In this session, we'll ask some questions about the nature of fear. What do we fear? Why do we fear it? Are there benefits to fear?

We'll then look in unusual places - the outdoors, the gym, the comedy club - in search of strategies for overcoming fear. We'll talk about how doing things that scare you leads to incredible personal growth.

You'll leave this session ready to stare fear in the eyes, and take control of your career.
notes:
Aside from coding, I have many hobbies. Most of them happen outdoors. I have noticed that many lessons I learn in the outdoors also apply to my professional life. In looking for a pattern to these lessons, Iâ€™ve realized that many of them have to do with overcoming fear. 

Much of the inspiration for this talk comes from the scariest thing I've done in my career - becoming a speaker at dev conferences. I have gotten so much from speaking, and I want to inspire others to overcome their fears.

The talk is divided into three sections. First, with help from the audience we talk about things that we fear. Next we talk about the science and emotions behind fear. The third section provides the audience with 10-15 strategies, some small and some large, to overcome fear. Strategies covered include risk matrices, fear-setting, and rejection therapy.

Slides: [http://bit.ly/do-scary-things-and-grow](http://bit.ly/do-scary-things-and-grow)

I presented this talk at Dev Up in St. Louis, in October, 2017. Some reactions from Twitter:

* [https://twitter.com/SuzCST/status/920352265243947010](https://twitter.com/SuzCST/status/920352265243947010)
* [https://twitter.com/Scott_Addie/status/920336252280475649](https://twitter.com/Scott_Addie/status/920336252280475649)

name: Joel Tosi
bio: Coaching and pairing within and across teams on how to leverage new technologies to drive product learning.
title: Metrics that Matter - Moving from Easy to Impactful
abstract:
Metrics are the bane of many organizations, getting fascinated on measurements that don't matter or can drive improper behaviours.
In this session, we walk through a simple grouping for metrics where the groupings not only call out the metrics, but their limits, and help guide to better metrics.
description: This session is a walk through of a popular blog post we did on metrics.  In general, we are leading transformations where the standard questions around metrics (velocity, bug, mttr, come up) - and we use these groupings to help organizations to get some answers for questions they want, but also understand their limits.  I.e. if code coverage goes up, that might be good directionaly but does not say we are getting code coverage of the important code paths.  We wrap up the session giving examples of more impactful measurements and walk through process behavior charts to help separate signal from noise in data.
notes: Just a projector and a whiteboard.  After that it is just math

abstract: The talk explains "How to build loosely coupled Microservices using Event Driven Architecture" We will use Azure Serverless functions to Build Microservices and will loosely couple them using a Event driven Messaging Platform like Event Grid keeping the Microservices state unaware.
description: The talk explains "How to build loosely coupled Microservices using Event Driven Architecture" We will use Azure Serverless functions to Build Microservices and will loosely couple them using a Event driven Messaging Platform like Event Grid keeping the Microservices state unaware.

abstract: This talk introduces the basics of ModelOps, Model Lifecycle Management, an operational model for data science team work products, and common open-source tools for achieving a minimum level of transparency, reproducibility, and risk management for those produces.
description: Data science projects are most visible right after initial delivery, but the data science teamâ€™s responsibility goes far beyond that. This talk introduces the basics of ModelOps, Model Lifecycle Management, an operational model for data science team work products, and common open-source tools for achieving a minimum level of transparency, reproducibility, and risk management for those produces.

name: Jim Holmes
bio: Jim is an Executive Consultant at Pillar Technology where he works with organizations trying to improve their software delivery process. He's also the owner/principal of Guidepost Systems which lets him engage directly with struggling organizations. He has been in various corners of the IT world since joining the US Air Force in 1982. Heâ€™s spent time in LAN/WAN and server management roles in addition to many years helping teams and customers deliver great systems. Jim has worked with organizations ranging from start ups to Fortune 10 companies to improve their delivery processes and ship better value to their customers. When not at work you might find Jim in the kitchen with a glass of wine, playing Xbox, hiking with his family, or banished to the garage while trying to practice his guitar.
title: More Better Quality Coverage
abstract: A practical talk walking you through the sorts of conversations you need to have in order to build a high-quality feature. Conversations start immediately when a stakeholder has an idea, and continue all the way through pairing on writing code--and finalize after the feature is in use.
description:
How do you ensure your feature's well-built and does what the customer needs (which may be different than what they want)? How do you ensure the feature's high quality? When do you discuss things like test case construction? Test data creation? Performance needs? And let's just skip by security because that's scary.

In this session we'll walk through creating a critical business feature. We'll take the journey all the way from ideation through production monitoring. You'll learn where to have various conversations about quality, and what you might consider along the way.

You'll see examples of good conversations used to help business focus on high-value features. You'll also help build out solid acceptance criteria, and you'll learn where to tie those pesky "Non-functional requirements" in. We'll tie all this together with working tests and code--and you'll see how exploratory testing fits in along the entire journey.

Make sure you're getting the best quality coverage of your work!
notes: I've given this talk at a number of conferences in 2016, 2017, and 2018. Slides here: https://speakerdeck.com/jimholmes/more-better-quality-coverage

title: .NET Reboot
abstract: As 15+ year .NET veteran, I wan to share my story of change with you. I will show development with the new .NET Core platform and related tooling. It's adapting to the new tooling rather than fight it or put it off.
description: If .NET has been your tool for years, the new approach and direction can seem a bit daunting. In this presentation we will cover the .NET Core platform and its tooling. We will cover development on macOS and Windows. It's a new .NET so let's explore everything it has to offer!
notes: .NET Core is a great "reboot" of the platform. Focused on allowing you to build different applications by using the language and libraries you've known for years. My intent is to show existing .NET developers this "new world" and answer any questions they have. We're all on this together, so it's best to share and learn from each other.

title: .NET Yesterday, Today, and Tomorrow
abstract: Want to modernize your existing .NET applications? This talk will help you figure out how to use the .NET Standard to port your legacy code into new applications built with .NET Core and still maintain backwards compatibility.
description: Trying to make sense of .NET Core and .NET Standard? Looking for ways to reuse your current .NET Framework code? In this session we will cover how you can take your existing .NET Framework code and reuse it in your .NET Standard/Core applications with ease.
notes: The purpose of the presentation is to show .NET developers how they can easily migrate applications to the .NET Core platform. Most of the .NET developers out there are unsure of all the changes around the platform, this presentation is meant to help close the gap.

bio:

I found much more happiness doing backend stuff so I focus on scalable backends and devops tasks this days.
title: Nitpicking terminology: are we using the right terms?
abstract: While we are developers, first and foremost we are human beings, terms and their meaning do influence our daily lives and ways we do our work.
description:
Is my code violating 'Single Responsibility Principle' or 'Separation of concerns'? What is 'technical debt' and is it comparable to 'financial debt'? 

Some teams have leaders, some have managers, what is the difference and should we care about it? Definition of a team seems to be completely broken; legacy is considered a dirty word and project managers seem to manage nothing. 

Having effective communication should not be 'a nice thing to have,' and I do hope you will join me in the discussion on these topics: your input is very valuable.
notes:
I have done this talk as keynote on WebCamp Zagreb 2018.

I have done this talk on 2 meetups: 
Infinum Server Side talks, 2018-03-16 https://www.meetup.com/Infinum-Server-Side-Talks/events/248254433/ 

PHP Srbija meetup, 2018-02-20, https://www.meetup.com/PHPSrbija/events/247645194/

title: No More Forms: Easy Payments with the Payments Request API
abstract: Filling out credit card forms is a huge barrier to mobile users making web purchases. The Payment Request API alleviates this issue by integrating native payment flows into websites. This talk will outline how this API works, which payment processors support it, and it can be used in existing sites.
description:
The Payment Request API is a new Javascript API that has already been adopted by most major browsers. This API, targeted towards mobile web users, simplifies the process of users making online purchases and adds additional layers of security.

This talk will explain how this API works and how it integrates with supported payment processors. It will include a brief demo of how this new payment system can be integrated into an existing web-app, and discuss libraries that simplify this process.

name: Bill Dinger

After that, Bill spent almost a decade working in infrastructure support focusing in the Microsoft stack. During that time Bill has done everything from troubleshoot dial up connections in rural Nebraska to building the digital experiences for some of America's most well known brands.

When not working, Bill will probably be found on his bike exploring gravel roads in his hometown of Lincoln, Nebraska.
title: OWASP Top 10 Vulnerabilities & ASP.NET
abstract: In this talk we'll go over the new 2017 OWASP Top 10 vulnerabilities and how they apply to ASP.NET. We'll include a demonstration of each vulnerability, the risk it poses, how to detect the attack, and how to mitigate it.
description: The Open Web Application Security Project (OWASP) Top 10 list are the most commonly exploited security threats found on the web today. Securing your applications & clients against them will go a long way towards mitigating any security risks and protecting your application from these threats. In this session, we'll go through each of the top 10 vulnerabilities showing you the vulnerability in action, what the impact is going to be, how to detect it and most importantly how to fix the problem. Code samples will be freely available and we'll examine the vulnerability in both MVC/WebApi & Asp.net web forms applications.
notes:
My company writes Asp.NET web applications for clients all across the world, and methods & principles of securing these applications to prevent attacks is a core function of our business. In addition, in recent years I was responsible for a number of PCI DSS level 1 secured web applications, and a few websites which are under attack by state level actors which necessitated learning about OWASP and how to translate these topics to junior and mid level developers on the project, as well as ultimately ensuring none of these attacks were present.

This talk has been given at a few conferences before  - Nebraska.Code(), Prairie.Code(), KCDC, BuildStuff(Spain), and DevUp in St. Louis

title: Provisioning and deploying to serverless
abstract: Provisioning a single serverless app can even be done by hand, but start thinking in tens or hundreds of them, and you'll have a challenge. Now think about connecting everything you've just provisioned to your CI/CD automatically. Don't worry... it's easier than you think, so come see how to do it.
description:
Fear not... whatever you can do by using Infrastructure as Code can be done by hand through a GUI, given enough time... but there are probably better things to spend time on.
There is plenty Infrastructure as Code solutions out there, but there's a relatively â€žnew kid on the blockâ€œ that plays extremely well with serverless and allows you to perform wonders in minutes/hours rather than days. Please welcome Pulumi.
Serverless stuff is charged per usage so there's no penalty if you've deployed five function apps instead of just one. The reason why we need five or fifty or five hundred of them are the limits on how fast, and how big can your function app scale.
Pulumi will take care of that, but we also need to deploy some software to those functions / containers / PaaS / etc. Not only that, but before deploying we need to fetch connection strings for DBs / storage / cache that we've just provisioned, and that's where the fun start. Trust me, you don't want to set up a release definition for five hundred function apps by hand, especially if they're scattered across multiple clouds.
That's where the fun starts and where you start connecting Pulumi with some scripts that handle you CI/CD. My tool of preference is Azure DevOps, and you're welcome to join this half demo half mumbling talk.

name: Mat Warger
bio: Mat Warger is a consultant with Keyhole Software.  He enjoys learning new concepts and has leveraged this curiosity in positions ranging from startups to the enterprise over the past decade.  He can be found chasing the latest and (sometimes) greatest in a wide range of languages and platforms, including React, GraphQL, and the cloud.  Find him on twitter @mwarger.
title: Rethinking REST Practices with GraphQL
abstract: GraphQL is going mainstream and it's easier than ever to get started with your own GraphQL API! This simple demo will show how hosting a GraphQL API with AppSync gives you a flexible, self-documenting API that can serve as an fantastic alternative to RESTful web services.
description: GraphQL has proven to be a viable technology since its inception at Facebook, but is now going mainstream. It is a specification and toolset for querying your data in a structured way.  But - how do you get started?  In this session, you will get a soft introduction to GraphQL and see how it can change the way you think about your data.  Using AppSync on AWS, you can get up and running with a GraphQL endpoint quickly and easily.  You will see how it provides a flexible, self-documenting API that can serve as an efficient alternative to RESTful web services. No experience with GraphQL or AWS is necessary, but a general understanding of REST (and APIs in general) is a plus.
notes: I have found this technology to be fast and flexible - enabling me to ship a website very quickly.  I've been working with it since it was in preview on AWS.  Regarding this talk, no experience with GraphQL or AWS is necessary, but a general understanding of REST and APIs in general is a plus.

name: Evan Williams
bio:
My name is Evan Williams. Not the co-founder of twitter, nor the namesake of the whiskey. I am, however, a passionate Javascript developer. I've been developing web applications for 8 years now. In that time, I've grown extremely fond of modern web-development practices.

I love finding interesting problems within that space that I haven't encountered yet, and figuring out creative solutions for solving them. I also enjoy spreading knowledge I've found throughout my experience.
title: Re-use all the things! Keep your business logic out of it.
abstract: Using state management libraries is second nature to most UI developers by now. However, there are still many pitfalls developers fall victim to. Understanding the benefits of separating business logic from display logic helps write composable, highly testable, and flexible projects.
description:
UI developers know that the key to the success of a project is the ability to move quickly and react to changes to both the business needs & design changes. Modern web frameworks give developers the power to do great things, but also enough freedom to make poor decisions when it comes to the architecture of the project. As a project ages, these poor decisions hamper the speed & ease of development that frameworks offer.

The key to a fast & flexible project is the ability to reuse the building blocks of your application in as many ways as possible. This means separating the logic associated with the components that is specific to the use case: ***business logic***. No developer should have to be _afraid to make a change_ to a display component as a result of an overly complex web of logic!

Learn from my mistakes and come find out how I approach project structure and how to refactor existing code to match.
notes:
While I will be utilizing React in the talk to highlight my points, this talk will be applicable to any UX Engineer, as the concepts discussed will transcend frameworks.

My experience in modern web frameworks includes being a self-taught Angular 1.x developer who made all the mistakes one can imagine as well as a senior front end developer at Zillow, coming into a code base 3+ years old. I'm able to relate to the mistakes made, and know from past experience how an approach I used helped create reuse throughout the application as well as lending itself to easy testing.

I will talk about how to create separation in a new project where the reins are in the hands of the devs to make the right decisions, as well as how to identify and refactor an existing set of components to create reuse. I will also highlight the benefits by showing how these refactored components can have an increased reuse and the difference between the test setup & assertions.

abstract: Donâ€™t wait until the end of your project to do security testing.Â  Transform security from afterthought to continuously validating security every step of the process.Â  In this session you will see how your CI/CD pipeline can perform continuous validation with every check-in.

abstract: Talk is about the JWT Authentication with Auth0 which plays an important role in modern day application development where it is a lot more than just the login screen, People will get know about different ways of authentication and authorization, concepts that make up modern identity.

abstract: AWS serverless is the new kid in town but lets not forget data which is also critical for your organisation, in this talk we will look at the benefits of going serverless with your data pipeline, but also the challenges it raises. This talk will be heavily loaded with demos so watch out!

title: Serverless Webhooks: Friend or Foe?
abstract: Like the dark arts of wizardy, knowledge of Webhooks in Serverless is a closely guarded secret. The idea sounds intuitive; it sounds easy, but it's... not. Serverless newbies can quickly find themselves without a solution, resources, or any idea where to turn next. I can help with that!
description: Pairing an automatic notification with an event-based cloud architecture seems obvious; an application emits an event and 'code in the cloud' responds to it. Why, then, is setting up Webhooks on Serverless harder than getting gum out of your hair? Join me and untangle the mystery. In this talk we'll cover webhook fundamentals, compare webhooks from several different vendors, and then implement them on a serverless ecosystem.

name: Chris Holland

title: Shipping Early & Often with Better Software
abstract: In a World dominated by agile practices, we still find ourselves unable to ship software at a predictable pace. We'll explore many challenges that we face and offer solutions. We will position ourselves to ship software early and often, while harnessing "Change" as a catalyst for opportunity.
description:
Software Engineering can be extremely difficult and maddening. But it doesnâ€™t have to be. We'll take a look at the various challenges we face and explore practical ways to overcome them, to answer this question:

Can we put ourselves in a position to ship code earlier and more often?

Toward answering this question, we will explore 5 areas:

* Bad Code vs Agility â€“ What it means to be â€œAgileâ€ and the impact of Bad Code on Agility.
* Better Code: Enablers â€“ Enabling Concepts for Better Code such as TDD, Clean Code and Patterns, with an eye toward adapting them to various programming paradigms such as Functional and OOP. 
* Empowering OOP â€“ If OOP is to be chosen as a paradigm, weâ€™ll explore what it means to play to the strengths of this paradigm.
* Web Application Architectures: When building Web Applications, weâ€™ll explore various architectures that may hinder or promote a sustainable business fueled by better code.
* TDD: Better Fuels Faster â€“ Leveraging preceding topics, weâ€™ll put it all together in describing a workflow leveraging test-driven development for shipping better products ... faster, while delighting our customers.

The end of this talk will showcase code examples of a real-world Kata for building the service layer of a â€œRide Hailing Applicationâ€. It will also link to recorded Kata videos, as well as a â€œclean slateâ€ branch in my git repository to follow along. If you wish to take an early look at these videos, they are all available here: http://bit.ly/tdd-vids

Having made this case, weâ€™ll conclude with the positive impact this workflow will have on a teamâ€™s ability to ship new products and new features at a sustained pace, with high levels of predictability.

While PHP, Symfony and Doctrine are used for code examples, concepts in this talk are applicable to all PHP frameworks and environments, as well as other programming languages such as Java, and C#.

name: Corey Weathers
bio: I am a proud father & software developer who is passionate about demonstrating the magic of software. Having written code in some capacity since 2003, I have worked as a software developer, software tester, performance engineer, and consultant with Microsoft, Intapp, the IRS, and a number of higher education institutions. These days as a Twilio Developer Evangelist, I spend more of my time balancing the joys of parenting (which means Owlette is my favorite character on PJ Masks because my daughter said so) with developing and sharing applications that delight developers and users alike.
title: Should I Use Blazor for My Next App?
abstract: Blazor is exciting and brand new, so exciting that the possibilities seem endless. But are they really endless? In this session we're going to talk about the highs and lows of building a real world application (Twilio Jukebox) using Blazor, JavaScript & C#
description:
Blazor, Meet Real World
====================
As developers we get excited when we hear about new technologies. [Blazor](http://blazor.net) is one that's taken the .NET developer community by storm. There is a lot of intro content on how to get started or what you can do with Blazor, but not a lot that speaks to how to solve problems you may come up against with Blazor. In this session, we're going to talk about some of the highs and lows of WebAssembly, Blazor & Razor Components, and explore potential solutions to standing up a real world application built with Blazor with Javascript, and C#
notes: I've been a .NET developer since 2004, when I was an undergraduate CS major. I've lived through the highs and lows and have become passionate about finding ways to share what I continue to learn but also to help other developers along their journey. It's for this reason I became a developer evangelist with a great company, Twilio, that continues to find ways to inspire and equip developers amongst their respective language communities. It's that same passion that drove me down the road of Blazor - so much so that I'm creating a new video stream in January dedicated to this same topic. I'm excited to possibly share what I know with the community at Connectaha

name: Chad Green
bio:

Over the years, Chad has managed groups from 5 to 63 people and worked on projects in a wide range of markets including healthcare, military, government, workforce management, financial services, chemical research, and electronic commerce.

One of the ways Chad has kept up with technology and development practices is by attending user groups and software development events throughout the country. Being a big believer in giving back and wanting to ensure that there are cool events for other software development professionals, Chad founded and chairs the annual Code PaLOUsa conference, organizes the Louisville .NET Meetup user group and the Monthly Tech Leader Coffee and Discussion, and has helped with other groups like the Louisville Tech Ladies and events like Cincy Day of Agile. Chad also speaks at user groups and conferences about .NET development, VSTS, and leadership.
title: Software Craftsmanship for New Developers
abstract: As a new developer, knowing language syntax is important; but just as important is understanding the concepts of software craftsmanship.  In this session you will learn about terms like code smells, DRY, and SOLID.  Even if for experienced developers, this will be a good refresher on the essentials.
description: As a new developer, knowing language syntax is important; but just as important is understanding what software craftsmanship is.  In this session Chad will talk about what the software craftsmanship movement is all about and why it is important.  Chad will also explain important craftsmanship terms like code smells, DRY, and SOLID.  Even if you have been developing for a while, this session will be useful to brush up on how not to be a developer but how to be a professional developer.
